Text.content: In a real world scenario, one typically starts developing a template JSP by transforming a static HTML prototype, as provided by a design agency for example, into a template JSP.

By convention, all kinds of static resources such as CSS and JavaScript files are stored in a module folder called resources/, for example, at /system/modules/org.opencms.examples/resources/css/agency.min.css.

Include CSS file and other static resources in the head section of your template JSP by means of a <cms:link> tag and the %(link.weak:) macro as shwon in the example below. The macro has the advantage that—if you once rename or move a static resource file—OpenCms will automatically adjust the link in the template JSP.

The example below renders a nicely styled notification using some class names from the included CSS.

Text.content:
Since a template is getting larger and larger over time, it is good practice to split the template JSP into several parts. For example, the header section and the footer section of a website may themselves be quite extensive JSP code blocks. Store such code blocks into their own header.jsp and footer.jsp files and include the JSPs by means of a <cms:include> tag and the %(link.weak:) macro. By convention, the right place for included JSP files is in the elements/ folder of a module, e.g., /system/modules/org.opencms.examples/elements/.

Note that all parts of a webpage that are defined in the template JSP or in outsourced JSP files cannot be edited by a content editor. If you want the content editor being able to change information in the header section or the footer section, use a <cms:container> instead as explained below.
